concept.title: Instruments
concept.shortdesc: The following instruments are installed on the B-25. You need no special instructions for their operation, as they are basically the same as those on any 2-engine bombardment or training airplane.

section.title: Flight Instruments
section.p: A static pressure selector valve on the instrument panel allows the. pilot to use an alternate source of static pressure from inside the airplane. Use this when the static side of the pitot tube fails because of damage or unusual air conditions, such as might be encountered during a thunderstorm.

section.title: Vacuum Instruments
section.p: Vacuum pumps, one on each engine, supply the pressure to operate these instruments and also the autopilot and the de-icer boots.

A bank-and-turn needle-valve control on the instrument panel allows adjustment of the suction pressures operating the gyro of the bank- and-turn indicator. Flight tests on this instrument should give a standard-rate turn (90Â° in 30 seconds) at one needle- width deflection. Adjust the suction pressures until this deflection is accurate.

section.title: Miscellaneous Instruments

ol.li: Air pressure gages— for the emergency air brake system and the hydraulic accumulators.
Landing gear and flap position indicator— this is a resistance-type indicator.

section.p: A contact, linked to the landing gear and flaps, moves across the arc of a resistor as you operate the gear and flaps. Thus the resistance varies and is converted to an indication of position on the instrument dial.

section.title: Autosyn Instruments
section.p: Autosyn instruments are electrically operated. Each instrument consists of two motors, one of which is a transmitter and the other an indicator. The transmitter is located at the source of mechanical energy, the indicator on the instrument panel. The two motors are synchronized so that the speed of the motor at the source governs the speed of the motor at the indicator, and gives an accurate reading.

section.title: Pressure Transmitting Instruments
section.p: Pressure forces in the pressure transmitting instruments actuate a diaphragm. This diaphragm transmits the pressure through a line filled with compass fluid to an indicator on the instrument panel, where it is converted to the desired reading.
The pressure transmitting instruments on the B-25 are fuel pressure and oil pressure.
Aircraft with these instruments have direct reading manifold pressure gages and electric tachometers.
